reviewText:
Great game, one of the best SHMUPS I've ever played. If you're familiar with Layer Section/Gunlock/Raystorm, then you'll have some sort of idea of what to expect with Kamui.

As with Layer Section, the gameplay is split into two layers, the plane you're on, and everything beneath you. On your plane, you can shoot a machinegun-like weapon and a  powerful laser that uses energy, but also destroys enemy bullets. On the layers beneath you, you can attack enemies with a lock-on lightning weapon - this can be used to destroy or damage enemies before they become a threat, or attack enemies shooting you from below.

The more you use the bullet-soaking beam, however, the less energy you have for the lightning attack, so it's a double-edged sword. This makes the gameplay significantly about energy management in the short term (as you do recharge quite quickly). The scoring system ties in to this, as kills with the lighting attack recieve a multiplier.

Gameplay aside, it's a nifty little game with an amazing soundtrack - and while the graphics are a bit dated, they're well made; there are really neat parallax and explosion effects to see.

If you like shmups, check out Kamui. It's a good'n.
voteText: 24 of 27 people (89%) found this review helpful 1 person found this review funny

reviewText:
Kamui is the Japanese word for divine or powerful.

This is a classic SHUMP game that I have really enjoyed so far. I have done a little research on this one, as I buy these Japanese titles a lot and usually have no idea what they are about.

So Kamui was originally released some 15 years ago as a SHUMP for the Japanese PC doujin community. The game is actually part of the Alltynex trilogy [http://alltynex.com/] with Kamui being the third game in the trilogy, but strangely enough the first one that was released to market.. go figure.

As a SHUMP it has the standard waves of enemies in a bullet-hell type environment. Using a combination of your weapons (which includes a lighting gun - which IMHO looks really cool when you fire it), power-ups and kill-streak combo(s) you can really rack up some high scores.
What I personally really like the is UNLIMITED continues so that people like me can actually finish the game.

It would appear that the game is the same as it was 15 years ago, with additional graphic and audio tweaks that bring the game in 2015 - so the DEVs should be proud of keeping the games originality intact while accessing some modern capabilities.

I picked it up in a Groupees bundle, but would have happily paid full price for it.

like SHUMPS? get it.

reviewText: A top-down shmup eerily reminiscent of Raystorm. I wouldn't really call it a Bullet Hell; the bullet count and speed are far more tilted towards the likes of Gradius than Mushihimesama or DoDonPachi, but nevermind that. This is a fast-paced shmup in which you have three weapons: the normal machinegun, which is rather underpowered; a screen-clearing shower of targeted lightning that only hits enemies on the plane below you; and shooting both at once releases a huge forward laser that clears bullets, deals ginormous damage and will be your best bet to survive the fiercer bullet spams. Both lightning attacks deplete a 'Lightning' gauge, but the lightning shower can be spammed even if your gauge is empty (though you'll get far less points per enemy destroyed).\n\nKamui is moderately hard, though you shouldn't feel discouraged, as the game offers infinite credits (though a 1 credit clear challenge is there if you feel like it, and it's bloody hard). Clocking in at about 30 minutes per run, I'd say the $8 price tag is slightly salty, though the game is VERY replayable and definitely very good. If you can get it on a sale (or a Humble Bundle, as has happened in the past), it's a no-brainer.

reviewText: Even little details like how the stages connect together are clever in design; there’s no obligatory rolling out of background tropes like the jungle level or the factory level just so boxes can be checked. KAMUI is a seamless journey stitching each of the six stages to each other, offering a rare glimpse of chartable progress from cloud-covered sky, through depths of earth into the outer reaches of the planet to take on an orbiting weapons platform. It’s a real labour of love that not only does credit to its esteemed source material but manages to out-perform it. It’s more forgiving, more fluid, more concise.\n\nFull Review // http://www.honestgamers.com/12435/pc/kamui/review.html
voteText: 4 of 7 people (57%) found this review helpful 2 people found this review funny

reviewText:
Kamui is shmup developed by Siter Skain and was recently brought brack to life by Nyu Media. It originally came out in 1999, but the gameplay stands up to the test of time. Initially I was concerned when I launched the game because the default display settings had the game so small, I found it hard to see all the bullets. They do provide a configuration utility which you can use to adjust the settings to your liking, which fixed the aformentioned issue I was having.

The game consists of six levels with multiple difficulty settings, with each taking about 5 minutes to complete. If you're the kind of shmup player who just likes to tear through shooters, you'll like that the game provides unlimited continues. In order to get the score based achievements though, you'll have to hone your skills.

Tight controls, nice difficulty, and solid gamplay make this a must have for the shmup pc player.

You can see my let's plays here:
http://youtu.be/GpJmAJpc_AE?list=PLKgGWqAhYeD_C2ud6AwVP3HuC62Gt4pGc

reviewText:
Yea!

This game is cool, as are all Alltynex games. Pretty difficult - but it's fun to play even if you fly the first level 20-100 times. Never gets old - and is fun to play even when you lose.

Graphics/Technical:
Graphics are... well they are good in the way they are done - but comparing to todays standards sub-par. The fact that it only supports a 800x600 resolution which is then stretched (to fit your vertical resolution) does not help much. Also the game only takes up 1/10th of your screen, when you are playing on a 16:9 monitor because the aspect ratio is locked in 4:3 and even then puts borders inside the 4:3 screenspace! There is an option to flip the display by 90° which lets you play sideways - yet sadly this does not enlarge anything. In fact it does nothing but confuse the crap out of you if you ever played the game normally. What a shame, because the game uses like something close to 16:9 flipped by 90 degrees. But these are technical problems due to the fact that the engine is badly optimized for today's standards. Essentially the graphics are great if you take it down to 16bit-era or more likely 32-bit era standards. They are Aesthetic" and the explosions do satisfy (because this word has been getting the hype recently - like gamers never knew what looks good or something...!..!).

Sound:
The music is
recommended: oldschool. It's something better than MIDI but not quite much more. The soundtrack is great though. Fast paced music that makes you want to dodge those bullets and shoot everything down. The music is an essential part of the game

reviewText:
If you love Raiden, you will love this. These were my favorite arcade games as a kid. I could spend all day playing these and Pac-Man.

It is a fast paced shooter, with 3 forms of attacking. Lightning lasers for enemies under you, bullets for enemies ahead of you, and a powerful laser attack that deals a ton of damage and can destroy 99% enemy attacks, so use that wisely, it runs out quickly.

It is about a 30 minute gameplay, faster if you can do it on 1 credit.

10/10 Runs well, plays smooth, and fun and challenging.

reviewText: As a bullet hell fan, I can very safely say that this game has gotten very close to the top of my favorite bullet hell games. The combination of the lightning and the bullets to make a multi-dimentional game forces you to focus on two different fronts which ultimately makes it VERY complex, yet simple at the same time.\n\nAnd for those of you who fear that it will be too difficult, the easy setting is quite generous to newcomers of the series.
voteText: No ratings yet

reviewText:
A fantastic Shoot 'Em Up that's also great for people who suck at Shoot 'Em ups (Like myself).
The main reason that KAMUI is a great choice for those who suck at shoot 'em ups is that it has seemingly infinite re-try's. Another things that make this game a bit easier is that you have a generous amount of health, you can take 6 hits before losing a life and you get 3 lives per try (At least on easy you do).  In short the game is very forgiving, it's actually the first shoot 'em up that I managed to beat in awhile.

Graphics: Look a bit dated (the game first game out in 1999), but I think they add to the charm of the game

Soundtrack: Amazing, So good in fact I will by the soundtrack (also on steam) when I get some cash to spare

Gameplay: Great with some interesting elements which I will explain
-The game has two layers the main(upper) layer which you are on, and a lower level.  There are enemies on
both layers, but the ones on the lower layer can only be killed with a certain attack, you also can't crash into to enemies     on the lower layer.
-You have three attacks, you primary attack is a basic machine gun attack that can be up-graded with power ups.  Your other two attacks are special lighting attacks.  The 1st of these attacks is a multi-enemy lock-on attack, this is also the only attack that can hit enemies on the lower layer.  The 2nd lighting attack is a powerful beam attack, this attack can also block enemy projectiles, making this attack you you most powerful offensive and defensive tool.
-The two lighting attacks have a drawback, they are both powered by the same recharging bar, so you have to decide how to use them, to attack the lower layer, to attack of the main layer, or for defense.

A fantastic shoot 'em up with great gameplay and a amazing soundtrack.  A great choice for those who are bad at shoot 'em ups.

reviewText: Possibly the greatest shmup that i've ever played. Incredible bosses, fantastic gameplay, and an excellent soundtrack. Kamui is the best in the trilogy by far. The others don't really compare honestly. I've played a lot of other games like this, but this one really grew on me. The variability in bosses, weapons, and strategy along with the difficulty kept me coming back again and again. 10/10
voteText: No ratings yet

reviewText: KAMUI is a pretty fun top down, even more so for its low price and inclusion in the Humble Bundle. It has very fun mechanics that allow you to fire into the fore and background, hitting enemies before they can get on your level and cause you a more direct threat. This also goes for boss battles, where bosses will have entire stages in the back or foreground requiring you to use your lightning weapon to hit them. Its a solid game, but lacks a focus mode that I feel would greatly benefit it, similar to Touhou. I often times found myself getting lost in the quickly moving backgrounds, as they caught my eye more than my own ship. Another negative, is that the game itself is only about 30 minutes long, max. Despite having some negatives, it is overall a very solid and fun game.

reviewText: If you are a big Fan of the Japanese Arcade Shmup (Shoot em up) Genre, then This is a must have game! Especially if you are a big BIG fan games like Rayforce which is very reminisent of this game. Every bit of the game reminds me of Rayforce and Raystom from the lock-on system to the graphics itself! The graphics itself isn't great by today standards but wounderfully replicated the effects and graphics rayforce had back then. I would only recomend this game to fellow shmup fans and players out there especially the softcore ones who played games simmilar to Rayforce and other not so maniac bullet hell shooters. oh, and if you played Thunder Force V and digging it's music like me, this game will be a treat! The game uses the same PCM instruments used in Thunder Force V! I believe it's the same instruments and I love that they did that. This game brings back old 90's Shmup nostalgia to me. I wish I still have a copy of Thunder Force V and a fully functioning raystom PCB cabinet. Hopefully steam would be brining these great shmup titles like those I said earlier.

reviewText:
A great shoot em up game that re defines the difficulty rating.
Pros: Great Gameplay
Soundtrack is pretty great
Everlasting hours of entertainment
Works well as the second installment of the trilogy.
Controllers work great
Cons: Game like any games with similar style it is short.
Difficulty could bother some people.
Story is average and forgetable.
Overall: The game is a fun and difficult game that could provide many people hours of entertainment. Fans of this style of games will be pleased with this game while new fans or someone interested in this might buy it on a sales price. Overall it is a 7.5 out of 10.

reviewText: KAMUI is a shmup in the same series as RefleX and ALLTYNEX Second. It has great visuals and shooting mechanics like the rest of the series and is pretty tough, although this one has an option for unlimited credits (it's the only game in the series with that to my knowledge).
